title: Hypothermia
summary: Dangerous drop in body temperature below 95°F (35°C). Requires gentle rewarming and medical care to prevent cardiac arrest.

steps.title: Recognize Hypothermia
steps.description: Shivering (may stop in severe cases), confusion, slurred speech, drowsiness, weak pulse, slow shallow breathing, loss of coordination. In severe cases, person may appear dead. Call 911.

steps.title: Move to Warm Area
steps.description: Get person indoors or to shelter. Handle very gently - rough movement can trigger cardiac arrest. Remove wet clothing by cutting away if necessary. Call 911 for moderate to severe cases.

steps.title: Insulate Entire Body
steps.description: Cover with blankets, leaving only face exposed. Cover head and neck. Put blankets under person too. If outdoors, insulate from ground. Use body heat - lie next to person if necessary.

steps.title: Provide Warm Beverages
steps.description: If fully conscious and able to swallow, give warm sweet drinks. No alcohol or caffeine. No hot drinks - warm only. If unconscious, do not give anything by mouth.

steps.title: Monitor and Warm Gradually
steps.description: Apply warm compresses to center of body - chest, neck, head, groin. Do NOT warm arms/legs first or use direct heat. Monitor breathing. Begin CPR if needed but continue even if person seems dead.

warnings: Do NOT rub or massage person - this can cause cardiac arrest
Do NOT use direct heat like heating pads or hot water
Continue CPR longer than normal - people can survive severe hypothermia
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 for all moderate to severe hypothermia
Seek immediate care if person is confused or shivering stops
Any hypothermia in children or elderly requires emergency care
preventionTips: Dress in layers and stay dry in cold weather
Recognize early signs and seek shelter immediately
Avoid alcohol which increases heat loss
